1090076014921859073.text: 3/ In such a case, utility must be clearly defined and information made publicly available such that it is ubiquitously apparent that the short-term gain of a breach of trust cannot plausibly outweigh the present value of all future returns.

1073257343549353985.text: /16 TLDR: Pet Friends Resolver showcases some cool features of Snowflake, and helped us do the research necessary to learn about and improve our product.

1073257342886662146.text: /15 This in turn calls the regular transfer function on Snowflake, and the resolver functionality proceeds as normal, without having to keep setting and re-setting allowances every time. Sorry Javier, we didn't have this in place when you were building :( but you led us there!

1073257342240739330.text: /14 This is meta-transaction-supported, which is awesome. Basically, we get einFrom, resolver address, signature, amount (of allowance), and bytes param (which encodes a function call on the resolver). Then, we set the allowance, and call the function on the resolver.

1073257341477421057.text: /13 After discussion, this led to an exciting new development for Snowflake - a function similar to approve-and-call that allows developers to set an allowance on-the-fly, AND execute the corresponding function within the same transaction.

1073257340827287559.text: /12 THIS IS THE IMPORTANCE OF USER FEEDBACK. Javier introduced us to exactly how awkward the flow was of either forcing users to set high allowances up-front, which poses trust issues, or forcing two transactions every time a resolver's allowance was too low for a given function.

1073257340219080705.text: /11 This intrigued us to make changes to Snowflake that wipe away this complexity for Resolvers who choose to permission function calls by Provider instead of EIN (option 2 above). It tied into a broader complexity we discovered in our allowance structure from Javier

1073257339585789957.text: /10 Under Javier's approach, to do this he would need to maintain resolver-specific approved service-provider schemes. Gross.

1073257338688163840.text: /9 For those unfamiliar, meta-transactions are a way to pay the gas costs on behalf of an end-user. This is what we use in the Hydro mobile app.

1073257337832517632.text: /8 While there is no inherent problem with this choice, it does provide some awkwardness if he wants to enable meta-transactions on behalf of users

1073257337195020292.text: /7 Interestingly, he permissions user interactions by EIN rather than by provider. This is option 1 in the ERC 1484 best practices for Resolver permissioning (https://github.com/hydrogen-dev/ERC-1484/blob/master/best-practices/BuildingResolvers.md …).

1073257335911579648.text: /6 Beyond onSignup, Javier also recognizes end-users by EIN in his dApp. This makes his dApp more flexible to recognizing users who own multiple Ethereum addresses.

1073257335299207168.text: /5 second, he uses extra data bytes params onSignup. This is a feature we added to Snowflake after discussion with Javier because he helped us realize how it cleans up his onboarding flow. This allows his dApp to automatically build a user profile within the signup transaction.

1073257334674206720.text: /4 The fee is interesting within the context of a dApp store, since it allows applications themselves to exist as a marketplace and highlights a plausible monetization scheme for non-token dApps.

1073257333772439553.text: /3 Pet Friend Resolver, his dApp, showcases some of the powerful financial functionality of Snowflake. Let's start with Snowflake's onSignup feature. He takes advantage of onSignup in two critical ways: first, he charges a symbolic 1 Hydro fee.

1073257332954546176.text: /2 I want to take a second to highlight how incredibly cool Javier's POC Snowflake Resolver is.

1034471292911722497.text: thanks @fr33tuff for the call-out here (https://twitter.com/fr33tuff/status/1034468953441980417 …); definitely important to have differences in opinion - i'm surprised about the state of the results in aggregate, though I'm sure many individual differences exist in the philosophy behind responses

1034458414573924352.text: /21 Just because it's tech nerds rebuilding society this time rather than impassioned revolutionaries doesn't mean we need to think any less critically about how we are fundamentally changing the world we live in and the ethics behind our actions.

1034458413282074632.text: /20 Lots of questions, few answers - what's really important is that those of us fighting on the frontier for a decentralized future understand the role we play in crafting governance and societal structures in the same way anyone who has built any new society in history did.

1034458412082507776.text: /19 Or will custom choice become the new standard as society internalizes how to navigate decentralized systems the same way that we internalized how to navigate the internet over the last few decades?

1034458411142918145.text: /18 Is any enforcement even a real choice? The theoretical notion is that someone else can build a new wallet or front-end on the same smart contracts and remove the enforcement; how well does this hold up in practice? Will network effects come to dominate front-end schemes?

1034458409695944704.text: /17 If we do enforce secret-sharing in systems we build, is it fair to alienate some people and subject them to centralized systems when they may prefer true trustlessness? I trust my friends and family with my life, but not everyone feels the same.

1034458408592859143.text: /16 Of course, in a decentralized future a technical person has the flexibility to handle key-restoration however they want, but if we build simple UI that doesn't enforce secret-sharing, is it unethical for us to offload the responsibility of choice to the average consumer?

1034458406684377095.text: /15 So the real architectural and governance challenge becomes: to what extent should we enforce seed word restoration via Shamir's secret-sharing? In particular, when it comes to digital identity since at some level ID is kind of a cornerstone to a blockhain-enabled future.

1034458405237346304.text: /14 So I doubt most people would support creating infrastructure that provides no mechanism for key restoration; Shamir's secret-sharing (outlined in my initial poll) seems to be the best technical solution.

1034458403471601664.text: /13 Especially because, of course, in the real world, we're not all 99.99 percent competent at protecting our keys - the real average threshold is likely much smaller; it's not easy to be paranoid about your private keys....

1034458402053922817.text: /12 @NoahZinsmeister noted that we have to assess this 1/10,000 as a tradeoff against collusion in a selectively trustful world. Definitely worth noting! I might have too much faith in kindness and too little faith in responsibility, but I think the tradeoff is negligible.

1034458400934047745.text: /11 42 percent of my survey respondents, it seems, would posit that there be no mechanism for this 1/10,000 to restore their identity - despite their loss being a probability in aggregate rather than a shortfall in independent competence.

1034458399558324226.text: /10 But in aggregate, one in every ten thousand people, even in this profoundly competent world we've created, will lose their private keys - and correspondingly, their identities as well.

1034458397821861888.text: /9 In this world, everybody is confident to the point of arrogance - after all, from an individual's perspective, it's unrealistic that they would ever lose their private keys with a 99.99 percent threshold.

1034458396618051590.text: /8 This hypothetical world is also designed to be 'trustless' in the sense that people manage their identity via private keys.

1034458395754082304.text: /8 Leaving aside the literary arguments, here's a hypothetical: Let's pretend everybody in the world is profoundly competent at security and is 99.99 percent likely to never lose their private keys.

1034458394596397056.text: /7 It would be a horrible, sad world if the driving philosophy was "trust nobody." Trust is a beautiful thing when it isn't imposed.

1034458393526894598.text: /6 The real beauty in blockchain isn't about converting us all into "trustless" weirdos buried in our bunkers - it's about opening the door for selective trust rather than forcing us to trust large, centralized institutions in order to reasonably function in society.

1034458392356642818.text: /5 Sure, the products we're building and the general public blockchain ecosystem is building are designed to preserve the option for "trustlessness" - but in my opinion, trustlessness requires some more review on a philosophical level, with an eye for risk and practicality.

1034458391106801665.text: /4 The fact that 42 percent of respondents want to keep fragments of their keys to themselves suggests to me that the message of "trustlessness" has extended to the point of dogma. It's viewed as the correct answer under any circumstance with no eye for context.

1034458390116937728.text: /3 The poll was about Shamir's secret sharing; a practice that I feel will be important to the widespread adoption of blockchain technology. As a society, we will need to carefully consider how we implement Shamir's secret sharing as a norm in key management systems.

1029718881521295361.text: Note: if friends and families are holding fragments, it will likely be a social norm. They’d probably have them stored locally in a usb or something.

1029718878232948737.text: Note: custodial institutions could be governments, embassies, DAOs, companies, banks, etc. They will likely be doing this as part of their broader business model. They will also be holding fragments for many people, not just you - they’ll have standard database security

1029718875401842688.text: Note: whoever you select would have to verify your identity in some way once you’ve lost it; institutions would probably do this through biometrics, security questions - family/friends would do this just by inherently knowing you

1022576733323714577.text: On the mobile side, this new functionality will allow our users to interact with resolvers and identity information without risking compromising the 2FA wallet already loaded on their device for signing messages. We'd love feedback for those of you who follow on github /8

1022576732031868928.text: More to come on the changes we made that will protect your seed words in the changes I'll be making to the whitepaper in the next few days - stay tuned! /7

1022576730823909378.text: We're also removing the need for users to load existing seed words into new wallets to transact - we've got a pretty creative solution to this and are hoping it will help our friends at @metamask_io , @MyCrypto , and other wallet providers deal with fewer phishing headaches /6

1022576729708224518.text: We're moving much of this code to the resolver level - a dApp that will allow a user to make arbitrarily large identity claims and share identity information with certain validity through a merkle tree structure /5

1022576728626081792.text: We're getting rid of a lot of unnecessary inefficiencies in the core snowflake contract protocol which should significantly drop the necessary gas to mint a snowflake /4

1022576726923247616.text: Expect to see some changes to the snowflake code on github in the next few days and to the white paper as well /3

1022576725862043648.text: That was mentally exhausting, but I'm extremely excited about what we're building both from a user perspective and a back-end perspective /2

1022576724716998656.text: Two back-to-back loooong but extremely productive meetings about Snowflake; the first one was about the mobile app's functionality, and the second one was about the smart contract architecture /1
